question: Question_A_30
statement:
For questions \textbf{A29} and \textbf{A30} below, decide if the
statements are true or false. In each case give \emph{brief
justification} of your conclusion.

If vectors \textbf{v} and \textbf{w} in $\mathbb{R}^3$ are linearly
independent and lie in the plane P that goes through the origin then
$\mathbf{v}\times(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w})$ also lies in P.
sols:
The normal of the plane is given by,

\begin{align*}\mathbf{n}=\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w}\end{align*}

and therefore if a vector is in the plane it must be orthogonal to this
normal vector. Recall that vectors are orthogonal if the scalar (dot)
product is zero. Therefore we seek to check if,

\begin{align*}(\mathbf{v}\times(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w}))\cdot(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w})=(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{n})\cdot\mathbf{n}=0.\end{align*}

To do this we use the triple scalar triple product which for any three
vectors \textbf{a}, \textbf{b}, and \textbf{c} states,

\begin{align*}\mathbf{a}\cdot(\mathbf{b}\times\mathbf{c})=\mathbf{c}\cdot(\mathbf{a}\times\mathbf{b})=\mathbf{b}\cdot(\mathbf{c}\times\mathbf{a}).\end{align*}

Therefore we see that,

\begin{align*}\mathbf{n}\cdot(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{n})=\mathbf{v}\cdot(\mathbf{n}\times\mathbf{n})=0\end{align*}

by the virtue that parallel vectors have a zero cross-product. Therefore
we see that the vector $\mathbf{v}\times(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{w})$ is
orthogonal to the normal vector of the plane and thus lies in the plane
itself. Therefore, the statement is \textbf{true}.
hints: How do vectors in the plane relate to the vector $v\times{w}$?

If a vector \textbf{y} is in the plane then it must be written as a
linear combination of \textbf{v} and \textbf{w} since they span the
plane.
